Had alcohol dependency for years (like 30 years) finally stopped in 2020, unfortunately the withdrawl process caused me to have a hemmoragic stroke (blood vessel in my brain burst due to massive increase in blood pressure). Have had a few occasions involving drink since then however, the need for alcohol seems to have gone. By 'need' I mean having one drink and then wanting more, more, more. Seem to be able to take it or leave it nowadays, which is great. Down side is, I can't walk properly, can't use my left arm very well, in pain most days, constantly tired plus a miriad of other smaller issues. It was stopping drinking that nearly killed me and left me disabled, therefore, my advice is if you're trying to stop drinking try and wean yourself off. 'Quitting cold turkey' is what did me.

My Brother password away 4 years ago. ( He dropped dead ). The day he passed away was the day I quit drinking. My Mom was 93 at the time and My brother lived and took care of My Mom. Anyway, I decided that I would NOT have another drink because I had to be there for My Mom. I’m the last of Her 3 Kids so I silently made her a promise that I would be there till the end. Sadly She passed away 2 years ago but I just didn’t see any real reason to start drinking again. I’m going on 5 years Sober now. It’s still tough I have to admit. Drinking is easy. Not drinking in the hard part. I’ve found inner strength to not drink because of other reasons as I get older. Weight is down , No Hangovers , not worried about driving drunk , memory is good , to name a few. It’s a good feeling. I do Miss My Rolling Rocks but there’s plenty of Dr. Pepper to be had out there.  That’s My Story.

I did Dry January this year, 2022. I didn't know about the ensuing depression that could happen in the first few weeks. I stayed sober until June, when I left a toxic job. I thought, hey, a few beers on a hot summer night can't hurt, right? Until I realized I bought 4 6-packs in 2 weeks. And then my birthday rolled around. I went out to a lake with friends and had 2 hard lemonades, not realizing they were 8% alcohol. I was WASTED, so I dipped into the lake to sober up. THEN my friends wanted to go to a bar. I didn't really want to go, but hey, it was my B-day, ok, sure. I ordered 1 drink and nursed that for HOURS while I watched my friends get shit-faced. And I sat there, listening to one go over a story he'd told at least 6 times already, getting upset and belligerent, and it was like an anvil hit me on the head. WTF was I doing?? This is supposed to be FUN??? I'm miserable, I want to go home, not sit in a stupid bar watching this guy drink himself into a coma. So I quit again, this time for good.

I got prescribed the Vivatrol shot for alcohol which works great. BUT when I tried to stop, my doc office said, they wouldn't give me Librium. I said, "oh so want to kill me huh?" I had been drinking 10 to 15 beers a day, but the high content ones like 5.9 percent. They finally gave me only 2 days worth and several hours after my body was detoxing. Ended up sending me to the ER with DTs. I was hallucinating, walked like I had cerabal palsy (no offense), couldn't speak right, couldn't form words or would get the word wrong, throwing up, sweating constantly etc. The ER immediately gave me Librium on the spot and enough for 4 more days, thank God. Even still, it was ABSOLUTELY hell that went on for some days. Best med to take besides Librium is WATER, and tons and tons of it. It sure helped. But please please those suffering severely, NEVER stop cold turkey. You can very, very easily die!! Alcohol is THE only drug that coming off it can kill you. All the rest will make you feel like shit, but you won't die. Get proper help, if you have no doctor or an unreasonable one, go to the ER. I am on week 5 almost 6, and except for some fatigue still, feel 1000 times better. Sorry so long, just felt it was important to say. Good luck to all those struggling and may you make it out. Like I said, Vivatrol shot helps immensely too.

Thank you for this video. I was in the hospital yesterday because my withdraws were so bad I was having panic attacks. My body head to toe went numb and tingly and my chest tightened. I called 911 and it took a matter of minutes for the professionals to diagnose the issue and issue a proper treatment. My previous comment was made before I realized I had a problem and I discouraged the use of benzos. The ones they gave me to level me out have been extremely helpful. It's only day 2 of sobriety and I'm putting all of my will power twords not drinking. I've never felt so close to dying. If you need help don't be afraid to seek it. I have had 3 open heart surgeries and I'd rather have my chest split open again than go thru the withdraw symptoms. Let that be a lesson for us all. I watched my father struggle with the same thing and didn't understand until now how powerful of a grip it holds on your body and mind.
I was always the guy who said oh that will never happen to me. Here I am and here begins a new chapter of a happy and healthy future. Wish me luck and good luck to anyone in the boat with me.

Living in Asia I was given benzos to help me stop drinking. Made life thousand times worse. My wife could handle me until I started on those. It was like mixing acid and base inside my head. So much memory loss during that time. Started doing weird weird things, so I locked myself up determined to quit in a rehab center that closely resembled One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest but but with sweet nurses. Spent a week of hell but got past the physical need. Went home and two days later almost died from acute pancreatitis, spending ten days in hospital but checked out early as Covid was just starting. Doctors couldn’t believe my stats. Beat all previous records in the worst way. But I’m here today 2.5 years sober. Hardest part was the shame of my benzo period. Never felt the urge to drink, almost dying helped, but I thought my mind was broken for months. Do your research before ever taking benzos to stop drinking. Both can kill you when you quit.

I feel this applies to marihuana addiction also. I was dependent and addicted to it for 12 years, my mistake was smoking the most powerful stuff every time. Tried to quit atleast once every year, the most i could go on was a couple months, experienced psychosis to extreme levels, delusional thoughts, even after week 5 i would still feel sick, thought i was already crazy, even at times thought i was schizophrenic. I was scared, depressed, wanted to end it all. Even afraid of my self thinking i could go crazy and hurt someone, (delusional thoughts and psychosis can do that to you) but it was a symptom and i thought at the time it was me with a damaged brain and damaged thinking pattern that thought i wasn't going to be able to heal. My heart would race so bad i was taken to the hospital 7 or 8 times in 2 months, at times with blood pressure so high i was told i could get a heart attack, slept 3 hours per night at most, crazy scary nightmares, sleep deprevation was driving me insane, crazy mood swings, prescribed xanax and high blood pressure medicine to ease symptoms, which end it up making them worse. My psychiatrist told me to quit them,  So i quit medication after 2 weeks which is enough for xanax to give you withdrawals (made me feel like week one). I would rarely get peace moments, ranging from only minutes to an hour at most, and then go back to anxiety and pain. But those moments where enough to see what i was missing on with my addiction.  i would go back to smoking to try to ease my symptoms, starting with very little and progressively getting back to high doses. What was my mistake? Trying to do it alone, going on day 34 today, but this time I've been going to AA  since the first week of quitting, excercising 5 days a week 30 minutes a day, all 7 days if possible. Quit gun games. Quit Facebook videos full of fights, accidents, death, dumb people doing stpd things. Quit porn as weed would lead me to it to calm euphoria and anxiety. Quit soda and sweets, as sugar rush would give me more anxiety. My body becomes sensitive to everything and anything. I was diagnosed with generalized anxiety, ptsd, with panic attacks and major depression disorder. Tried to end all a few times in the past. Not a pill fan so no medication to help me this time. Just spitting all out at AA tribune, excercise, eating healthier, visiting family members, avoiding places, people and situations that could trigger my anger, pain, anxiety, and addiction, feeling in the gap with work when i can because currently unemployed, cleaning home, spending time with wife and kids, working on small projects like cleaning the cars and whatever i can do to distract my pain. Eating a healthy breakfast, Not eating after 9pm only maybe jelly or yogurt, and i sleep much better. also swimming decreases my inflammation. Drinking lots of water everyday, showing love to those around me,  and trying not run too fast in my recovery. But most of all getting closer to God, much prayer asking for forgiveness, help, and a chance to recreate my life and recover all the time wasted.   I been understanding myself better, learning I've been my worse enemy, so trying to forgive myself to let go of the past and let go of the person ive been, or else it's like heavy chains on my body and soul that keep trying to make me think i will always be that person, and if i dont let go of that i wont be able to become someone new and free. trying to transform my habits, my thinking, my actions. It definitely a battle, that's why i have needed all those things and much more to feel in the emptiness before depression, anxiety, remorse, and pain take over and i go back to addiction. Im still a recovering addict, im understanding i was looking for peace in the wrong place, peace in marihuana thinking it would relax me, but was just making my body, mind, and heart sicker. Now im looking for that peace in all the mentioned above, im starting to appreciate soberness, everything smells, looks, seems, much brighter, much more positive, i am now hopeful for the future, im putting my faith in God and trusting He is with me on this journey, to being clean, to actually living. I have alot to work on, mood swings and old thinking patterns, all together with the physical pain that comes with abstinence, but the peace moments last longer as i get closer to detoxing, this time has been different, because im looking for all the help i can get, and actually using it. when i wake up anxious, i pray to God for help and peace, and end up Falling asleep again without notice. When i wake up in the morning i thank God for letting me see the sunlight once again, I thank him for my family, our health, our food, our home, the sun, the air, you name it, alot to be thankful for! .. Loosing a parent, loosing a child, having a chronic decease, are some of the harshest and hardest things in life, and i add recovering from addiction to the list. I pray that everyone who wants to change their lives around will make it, that they will get the help they need and take action in the right direction, I pray they never give up, i pray for God to help them heal and see the future with hope, and that they can recover faith and love in themselves, and most of all that they reach peace in their hearts to never need to go back to any type of addiction. I pray for healing for the sick, help for the poor, and i wish you all new beginnings in your bodies, minds, hearts, and souls! You can do it! Even when you feel alone, you are not, there are many of us who get you! Who understand what you are going through. We're all on this together, from different parts of the world! From different paths and upcomings! We are a sister/brotherhood. I am writing this from a peaceful moment laying on my bed, thankful for another day. Take it day by day, dont try to run. Its a journey to a new life, takes time and be patient with yourselfs, show love to those around you, forgive and forget, let go of the past, look for new begginings. Not just in the outter, but also within you! Love you all and pray we all find meaning in our existence, and true happiness and peace in our hearts. 💙 I will end this message for you like i end my tribune at AA, I thank God for this past 24 hours sober and thank YOU for your tolerance! 🙏

Hear me out. We all have to die somehow brother. I have to work to live, and existing(while sober) is just that. Existing. I've had a rough one since the word "go." While I was sober until my 29th year, making the best decisions that I could for myself, the cards just weren't in my favor.
While it may be denial, I interact with people better, Im punctual for my job, do it consistently and just have a better outlook whilst inebriated. While it's not for everyone, and I appreciate everyone's choices, I want to live while I'm alive and not have second thoughts of "I wish I did this or that" because in all honesty, not everyone is born into fortunate opportunity. I'd rather be in good spirits and enjoy my time here (may it be half the time) then drag on a mediocre, lackluster, painful life until Ive outlived everyone who gives a crap about me.
If alcohol has a negative effect on your life then seek help, don't drink and drive, and treat others with respect.

From 1970 to 1983 I drank quantities you wouldn't believe so I'll skip telling you, but I had an aunt and an uncle who were also huge drinkers too so it was in my family. On May 1, 1983 I came within a slight squeeze of a trigger from blowing my alcohol soaked brain all over a wall. I checked into a rehab the next morning with a BAC of .386. The Doctor said I should be dead. I told him that inside I was dead and I was there to see if I could rise from the dead. Amazingly I experienced none of the stuff this guy was taking about. After 13 yrs of being constantly drunk all I felt was GOOD. That feeling remains to this day and this past May 2, 2022 I celebrated 39 years of sobriety and I have had no desire whatsoever for anything with alcohol in it. I can be around people who are drinking as long as they are not drinking just to get drunk ( like I used to do). Drunks I avoid like a plague. Seeing them and their behavior stirs too many memories. I don't do that out of fear I'll start up again. If that ever happens I will pull that trigger before I'll take even a sip. It takes a tremendous amount of will power to succeed. If you want it bad enough you can beat it. I'm living proof of that.

If you consume alcohol to get inebriated you will develop an addiction. The natural course of any behavior is to increase it until you die or are forced to stop because of financial or other specific reasons. This may lead you to make more poorer decisions and maybe end up lowering your standards and mixing with crowds who share the same habit. This happened to me but stopped when I could not take more chances with getting in trouble with the law or making my life at home more strained while keeping the habit. The problem is once you start in one circle you may try to carry it over to others and in doing so cause a problem in your life. This was my experience. I just reached 10 years of sobriety and had the habit over the course of 22 years with 14 years actually engaged in drinking. 14 years is long enough to say the drinking was not helping as much as I liked to think it was. It was a social lubricant, something to do, and an easy way to escape. At some point your behavior becomes a responsibility that reflects on others and may influence their judgements. That is a reason to stop.

Never drank alcohol beyond a few sips here and there until I was 18 at the end of high school. Now I’m almost done my freshman year of college and it’s starting to scare me how much drinking has become a part of my weekly routine this year. I got shitfaced pretty much every weekend usually 2 times a week and sometimes 3. I realize this is fairly common for college, but something is telling me I need to quit. I don’t act out in dangerous ways or take wild risks when I’m drunk. I’m actually quite pleasant and happy from what people tell me, and I know for certain that I’ve never gotten violent or verbally abusive when drunk. I’ve just been feeling pain in my stomach and my lower back and waking up confused a lot of the time and I’m concerned that I might’ve damaged my liver from binge drinking on weekends. I realize there are other people who have been drinking heavier and longer than I have, but I feel like if I don’t take a break, I’m going to end up hurting my physical health severely if I haven’t hurt it already. I decided April 30th would be my last drink of alcohol for a while. I just don’t want to be blacking out anymore and I want to be able to enjoy drinking reasonably later in my life and I’m really worried I could really mess up my body if I let this go on for 4 full years of college. I’d love to hear people’s thoughts on if I might already have health issues, or even if this break is a good idea. Who knows if I even have something to worry about, but I do sense something is off about my ability to concentrate and be on top of my work, and I’m not sure if it’s just my inclination to always socialize or my drinking
TL;DR- freshman year of college has include a lot of binge drinking and I really think I should quit and figure out why I like it so much to hopefully prevent a serious problem

How to quit drinking: If you are moderate just be a man and deal with the 3 days of pain. If you are severe you don't have to go to rehab just research a medical detox in your area you spend 3-5 days there and they give you benzos and vitamin B1, B12 complex, and a special prescription to deal with cravings and withdrawal. Also read books to motivate you to quit. I recommend 'Easy way to control alcohol' By Allen Carr and 'Drink' by David Nutt. If you can't afford them download them on pirate Bay. Also for the first month use sugar and black coffee as a crutch.

Hi I'm Markham and I'm an Alcoholic. I started at the age of 13.. snuck around at moms work picnics in 76.. I drank to get drunk, never knew how to socialize with it. During the 80s we did house parties with kegs and bands in basements, plenty of blackouts and plenty of walking stumbling home.. chronic and stubborn patterns.. I finally hit rock bottom in 88. I was 25. Met God's grace and a good Friend willing to help me sober up.. 11/29-1988. It's now 4/6-2022 I am now 58.. better life, better friends, better foods, better life. Married man with 2 good boys and awesome wife.. my dad quit in 86, my mom and brother went in for treatment in 93, then my sister and her husband went In shortly after my mom did in 95. We all never went back, it devastated our youthful paths to successes but we managed as a family to support our new lives together!! Also I might add, we are native American people of the Navajo nation.

I use to drink very heavily and did so for at least a decade. It was a minimum of 8 cans of Guinness a day, and a binge every couple days where sometimes I’d go through 12 bottles of wine in one sitting. Today I’m coming up to 1000 days sober and the only side effects I had was a craving for sugar which I never had before and I also noticed that my libido was non existent. I’m British so drink a lot of tea and use to have no sugar but had to put a teaspoon in after I quit. I’m guessing the sugar craving was to replace the sugar that the alcohol would break down to and the libido was maybe a confidence issue? Who knows but I never had the shakes or anything like that and I went completely cold Turkey! As for the benefits the main one was a severe reduction in my general anxiety, and another severe reduction to the impact on my wallet 😂

About a month ago, I quit a roughly eight month long, all day-every day alcohol addiction. I went to the ER, hoping for inpatient treatment, but instead they just gave me some librium and told me to kick rocks. So I had to withdraw on my own. The first night was horrible. The worst part was the hallucinations. Weird, jittery spider webs with giant spiders crawling on them, all over my room, shadow people, bugs and rodents on the floor, it was really freaky. Didn't sleep a wink for the first 48 hours ish. But what's weird, and I'm not sure if the meds they gave me played a part in this, but I started feeling a lot better after the second day. My appetite came back, the anxiety and shakes slowly dissipated, and the hallucinations stopped entirely. By around day 7 I was basically back to what I would consider "normal". It was a far cry from what I was expecting. It might be a factor that this was my first bout with alcohol addiction, because of the kindling phenomenon, but I was still pleasantly surprised. Either way, one month clean now and I feel great. Zero urges to drink, zero symptoms.

I think it's also important to be aware of the tendency of switching addictions.  In my case, I was very overweight most of my childhood and while I lost weight during puberty, I started gaining again in my early twenties.  At 30 years old  and 315 pounds, I had a gastric bypass and over the next year started drinking and and developed an addiction to opiate pain killers.  When I tried to stop drinking and was forced to stop the pills, I realized that I was starting to use marijuana consistently.  It has taken me 10 years, countless lost relationships and opportunities to understand and what was happening and to start to heal from what I was really running from and using substances for in an effort to live in a state of being numb.  Please be aware of how easy it is to pick up new addictions while trying to quit old ones.

I drank to medicate myself, depression, anxiety, insomnia & ptsd plagued my childhood to adulthood. I got sick of drinking, I was a happy drunk at first, then a sad drunk and lastly a angry drunk. I embarrassed myself enough, got tired of hangovers and cleared up my foggy brain once I quit. I didn’t go to AA, don’t have cravings nor see it as an option and will b 6 years sober next week. Another benefit….I did not realize how much money I was spending on alcohol until I stopped, so now I put that extra $ towards travel, hobbies and eating out. This wasn’t luck nor being ‘lucky’, I don’t have anything against AA, you do what you need to that will help you. I do have medical issues that I’m also addressing, I’m in trauma therapy so self care is vital. It feels good to have control back and it’s worth it💝

It continued for about 2 years and I started noticing I often feel shitty in the morning, my mind gest clouded (which was a big drawback in my work), I started putting on too much weight, my running and swimming practice became harder.. But the thing that ultimately did it for me was imagining what not buing 800 bottles of expensive craft beer a year would do to my wallet :) One day I just decided to quit. I switched to water and, strangely, I never had any alcohol cravings. All 2019-2020 I drank every single day. Before work, during work, and drank myself to sleep every night. Started off with about a pint a day, then graduated to a fifth, and after that nearly a gallon. I lost so much…I lost my job, all my money, my girlfriend, and friends. I used to be in amazing physical shape and my health completely deteriorated. Liver issues, itchy skin and rashes, yellow eyes, gained 30 lbs, prostate issues, ulcers, constant nausea even when I wasn’t drinking…the list goes on. I was at rock bottom and trust me I’m just scratching the surface on everything I went thru. I went to the hospital with Covid because I had beat my body up so bad I couldn’t fight off the disease.

After finding a tumor on my liver I when I was in the hospital I made the decision to stop drinking. It lasted a little over 6 months and I honestly felt amazing. In the back of my mind I knew I still wanted to have a drink though. When the Dr told me my liver was ok I started drinking again slowly. Couple drinks here and there no big deal. Eventually the addiction took hold and for about 2 months I was back to drinking everyday. I also have bipolar disorder so I realized recently that drinking simply doesn’t affect me the way it does other people. I have to work overtime to take care of myself and drinking simply can’t be apart of my life.

Therefore, I made the decision to stop completely and this time around honestly feels different. I really believe in myself this time. I’m just under a month now and I feel great and I know I’m gonna succeed this time. I have tears in my eyes typing this because I keep thinking about rock bottom... I’ve been there twice and I refuse to go back again. I hope everyone on here is doing well and staying strong and I love y’all! Thank you for your testimonies you really inspired me to keep going!
Fantastic explanation! Thanks for this video!

I just quit after 40 years of heavy drinking. If you are a very long time heavy drinker you MUST see a doctor before you quit. I went to the ER and told them I was quitting and having very bad withdrawals. My withdrawals were horrible and if I didn't go to the ER I wouldn't be typing this right now. Don't wait more than six hours after drinking to see a doctor....you can have a seizure and it WILL kill you. Get to that doctor and get a prescription for Librium. Librium is the key to quitting safely. But NEVER drink alcohol if you're taking Librium, even a tiny amount...it WILL kill you. Quitting alcohol after years of drinking is VERY dangerous. Do it right and see a doctor or you will die. And that's not a joke.
Btw, in the U.S. about 1000 people die every year from the withdrawals of quitting alcohol. Don't be one of the them. Do it right with the help of your doctor and the proper medications. This is nothing to fool around with.

Caught the stomach flu last week for 1 awful night, with 3 day carryover, and used that as an opportunity to reset my cravings. If you are more of an only at home-consumer, I will say that one of the first steps is simply ignoring the alcohol store while you are driving home from work or doing a simple errand. That keeps it out of the house.
For me my body would be finally getting back to normal by Weds or Thursday (all that water weight will finally be off and gone from the prior weekend), and then I would again subject it to a simple 4-5 beer beverages for the evening for 2-3 evenings starting on Thursday depending on whether I had Friday off or not. I've gone over a week without any beer and I had forgotten how lightweight/quick my body can feel (granted I can 'get-fit' in about 1 month with 5 day per wk workouts from prior working out). My face doesn't feel weighed down either. Pants also are starting to fit a little looser already. Most importantly I wake up with a clear head! Once you achieve this little 1 week victory, it starts to get easier to say no and avoid the stuff.
In my case, I think I had cheated the 3 week stomach recovery period since I had puked 5 or 6 times in short succession over the course of 8-12 hours. Any toxins that were in my system were gone after that, and I had a clean slate after the flu passed.

Alcohol reacts to each abuser in its own way. I drank for almost 35 years, one day a week only, Saturdays. Never at home, never alone. Didn't like the taste of it at all, I loved the social stimulation of being at my favorite bar hanging out with friends. My problem is I could drink from 10:00am till bar closing time...and in Chicago, that could be 5:00am. I was a binge abuser. Never had a hangover either. Then one day, about 7 months ago, for no apparent reason, I quit. Still go out to bars occasionally, no problem, just don't drink. The thing is, life was much better when I drank that one day a week. I have a few progressive health issues not alcohol related, and go figure, all my lab work was better when I drank. I'm not thinking about drinking again, but seriously, I was hoping for a better return. Although I have saved a lot of money.

I'm a 24 year old alcoholic. I started when I was 16 and kept drinking up until September of last year. My drinking was a factor in many bad things that happened in my life such as damaged relationships/friendships, depression/ anxiety, physical injuries, homicidal thoughts and violence, suicide attempts, felonies, misdemeanors, and unplanned pregnancies. Alcohol use is not a joke, you don't want to end up like me. If anybody is reading this, and drinks every day "your mental health" or "you'r childhood trauma" is not the problem it's the alcohol, and if you want all of your problems to go away you have to start by putting away that bottle first, or you can live in constant terror, bewilderment, and fear, continue harming others, and slowly lose your physical and mental health until you reach the point of no return, which is usually an institution or a coffin. God bless and I pray that you find a road to recovery 🙏 🙌 ❤

Alcohol can be one of the most dangerous drugs to detox from acutely. Be sure to seek medical advice and support. Also, if you need emergency surgery or surgery of any kind, it is VITAL to tell your surgeon and anesthesia team, because the drugs that <reverse sedation>, can put a person into acute alcohol withdrawal syndrome (AWS), seizures, dangerously spiking blood pressure, fever and even death. This is one of the ways that patients die after surgery. Doctors can prescribe a benzodiazepine medication taper regimen, so that you can much more safely do a withdrawal plan over several weeks. (~a former addition MD’s spouse)

To anyone who is trying to stop drinking, believe me if I can do it, so can you. I spent my 20s drinking heavily and partying my life away. When I hit 30, I admit I forced myself to stop drinking. It was no longer going to control my everyday life. It took some work but after about two months it became easier and as time went on it didn’t even cross my mind to have a drink.

I ultimately went almost 2 1/2 years without drinking. I did end up having another beer one day to see if it would start to become part of my life again. See I never was a big drinker. Just was never my thing. Opiates however I was a big fan of lol. I will say something that may make some people angry but that’s life. If you haven’t been through addiction personally you’ll never understand what it’s really like 100%. That means ppl that come on these who’ve had a family member or friend who’s gone through it you’ll know to a certain extent but never all the way. It is possible to quit whatever you’re addicted to. With the right help and commitment you’ll prevail. For me 12 steps were not it. Don’t feel bad if it’s not for you. It’s alright. They will try to make you feel bad too. There are other things out there. I’ve seen people who have 8 years sober and haven’t went to one meeting or never had a sponsor. They aren’t required. Granted heroin and alcohol are different but I’ve been free of heroin since August 2018 and I haven’t been to a meeting that entire time. If you live in a state that it’s legal, try smoking weed. Anyway, I just wanted to say that I miss her so much!

She really was a beautiful soul...just in too much pain and tried to cover all that pain up with booze.

By the time she was put in the room she was dying.

She died with a beautiful smile on her face...I absolutely believe she wanted peace and was ready to go to heaven.

Her husband had to close her gorgeous blue eyes!!

Every school needs to teach the young that not only can drinking and driving kill you BUT you just may be the one who becomes addicted!!

Then pace around the house back and forth all while sweating like I am showering while walking, sipping on dollar store mouthwash because most people don't know that brands of mouthwash have 15%-23% alcohol in it. You babysit the mouthwash until about 5am, down it, and pull the covers over your head and toss and turn, irritated, paranoid for no reason, praying the sun hurries up and comes out because the empty dark and the still silence drives you insane….. 6am hits and you begin vomiting vice, rinse your mouth and search for $9.76 cents to buy another 5th of Taaka that will only last you until 4pm, but it’s ok because at least from 7:30am until 4pm, you can have alcohol in your system and function and try to make money…..4pm hits, you made some money, enough for another bottle and a $5 Little Caesers pizza, you’re elated and have a sense of security, not bdcause you have food and a place to go back to, but the fact that-you have enough liquor to last through the night…..you don’t have to sleep while going through withdrawals…..everything starts all over when the second bottle is empty at 6am…..

From February 1976 to June 1977 I was stationed in South Korea we drank alcohol on our off time. A lot. Some more than others. I had heard about people consuming alcohol until they drank themselves sober and thought it was a myth. That is until I did it one night in February 1977. It was the Saturday we had a going away party in the village at one of the clubs. The guy who the party was for, myself and two others started what was called a "thunder run" about 3 or 3:30 in the afternoon. We drank at least two drinks at each club before moving to the next. I drank mainly bourbon and Coke. From the Maxim Club and ended up at the Galaxy Club where I was feeling pretty good. I also invited a waitress I knew at a club to join me if she could get off. She did. Well, by the time curfew rolled around I was sober. The next morning when I awoke I felt as if I had not been out partying. Monday morning was different when I went to work. One of my coworkers, Able Vidari, asked me why did I do what I did to his lady. To this day I still don't recall. Later on my Property Book Officer, Mr Bayless, asked me who was the girl I introduced him to and I didn't recall until a decade later as I was looking at photos one day showing them to a friend. While in country I lived mostly on a Korean diet and when I came back to the States my system had trouble getting used to American foods. Try having the trots every day for a month. When I went out drinking it just made me sick. It was either go out drinking and be sick or go out and not drink and don't be sick. I don't like being sick. My buddies knew I had quit and why and then I became the "designated driver" before it became popular. Since I lived 90 miles from where I was posted they'd ask me on Wednesdays and Thursdays if I going home for the weekend so they would know if they had a sober driver over the weekend. I'll still cook with it though...

Love how all of us alcoholics are drawn like a magnet to this video. I'll share a little too, why not. By the time I was 25, I went from drinking only while going out to blacking out every single night without exceptions. At 28, the only time I didn't have a drink in my hand was when I was at work. When sober my hands were shaking so badly I couldn't perform basic functions like brushing teeth, I couldn't form full sentences or even words, my brain had this weird pulsating twitch topped with extreme fogginess, if someone talked for more than few seconds I lost track, I couldn't eat or even swallow my own spit without throwing up when sober. And the psoriasis part hit home too, it got so bad even with treatment that my knees and shins looked like my skin was peeling off of them. The crazy thing is that somehow I was 100% it was just my depression. As I was getting closer to 30, drinking stopped working, no matter how much I drank I couldn't feel at ease,  and THEN IT HIT ME, I realized I had a problem, the only solution left was to kill myself. When I turned 30 on Jul. 23, 2020 few weeks later I was living out of my car in my parents driveway, the only thing on my mind was to end it all, I thought it was too late, I was in pain 24/7, mental and physical, my eyes were yellowish, my resting heart rate was at 180 bpm, I was depressed and I was scared of being alive. Then on July 30, 2020, my mom woke me up by knocking on my car window and took me to straight to rehab. I wouldn't be here if not for my parents and everyone at Ashley Hope House! Even after all this, my mind still plays tricks on me from time to time telling me it's ok, but I know how to fight it this time!

Alcohol is a powerful drug. I hope this video shows more people why a person with severe AUD ("an alcoholic") isn't facing the singular choice of whether or not to put a bottle to their lips. Their body begins to torture itself when these people try to quit, especially those trying to quit absent a physician's care. I've seen people do it with and without meds. It's hard work, but each and every one of them would tell you it was worth walking a mile barefoot over glass.

I should add that the other side isn't instantly rosy. There are a ton of social issues to content with, ones you wouldn't have even imagined. Even this is another reason to get a physician's help when you try to quit. The physician will help guide you to other professionals, who they've vetted, that can provide effective assistance for you on the social and societal factors that you may find yourself facing. The people I saw come back to detox were most often the ones blindsided by some social circumstance. If you can see it coming, we can deal with it and gain you another sober day.

Lastly, if you relapse, it's not over. It's actually pretty damn normal. Sobriety is not some state that you scratch and claw to enter and BAM, you're in, or uh-oh, you're out. Sobriety is better thought of as more an activity that you do rather than some "this or that" state. Sometimes sobriety is easier to do, other times not so much. But you get better with practice. The key is figuring out what makes it easier and what makes it more difficult. A physician and their team can help you uncover those helpful and unhelpful things. Further, they can help you develop a game plan that will play into those innate strengths (what makes it easier) and mitigates the things that will make it difficult -- until you build up your strengths in those areas. Relapse is about learning, not condemning. This is actually true of all drugs.

Don't suffer alone. Please get help. Good luck.

Alcohol abuse is most often a form of self-medicating an underlying mental condition that is hard to deal with, as well as the physical conditions that cause alcohol to be processed differently.  If you seek medical help, like at a rehab, be sure to tell your doctor about ALL your emotions...good and bad.  We often don't mention the good feelings or good days with lots of energy, but those could be the days when we are manic.  Doctors seeing only depression can diagnose uni-polar depression and prescribe drugs that are seriously bad for Bi-polar disorder.  Tricyclics especially can cause more mania.  Remember meetings are good for the mind, but the brain is a physical organ, and understanding it helps to remove some of the guilt we feel about not having enough willpower.  Once I understood I had a physical problem with alcohol, it was so much easier to quit.  Going on 14 years...even without meetings.  Use whatever works for you.  People quit everyday.  Hell...I quit 365 times one year alone. LOL

1:05 Somebody who doesn't care about dying in a car accident caused by being drunk and doesn't care about other people around him doesn't have to have a severe alcohol use disorder if he decides to step behind the wheel. Because in that situation it has nothing directly to do with the alcohol itself.

His behavior doesn't say something about his alcohol use. It says something about his responsibility. If a person couldn't give two shits about the consequences because of severe mental issues for example, that person doesn't suffer from an AUD.

So as bad as drinking and driving is, I don't see how you could use it to judge how bad your alcohol use is. At best it shows how irresponsible you are after drinking. But you might as well be that irresponsible either way with or without the alcohol.

So it shouldn't "constitute" to severe AUD, instead it may infer to severe AUD or moderate or light, depending totally on how you act without the alcohol.
It is ok to drink in moderation. You don't have to be completely sober. If you can't though, then don't do it.

I treat addicitve substances like a credit card. You start with a balance of zero. If you consume a dose of alcohol, cocaine, caffeine, sugar, etc, it's like putting a charge on your credit card and now you have a balance. Abstaining from that substance is like paying off the balance. Consuming an addictive substance is just like giving yourself a boost now that you'll have to pay for later, there is no free benefit.

If you accrue a balance and pay it off right away, everything is great.

If you accrue a huge balance, it will be harder to pay it off, and the interest will wreck your life making a $1000 debt turn into $1200 or $1700 or $10,000 if you take long enough to pay it back.

If you think you can accrue a huge balance and get away with, you are horrifically wrong.

When you consume an addictive substance, you need to have a plan for how that fits into your life's plan so it doesn't get out of control and start harming your life. It's okay to have some of anything you can imagine if done responsibly, but that means something slightly different between individuals and substances.

I'm not going to argue with the science, which is correct, but well meaning episodes like this can put people off stopping... By talking in the weeks and weeks time frame to people who have trouble thinking of making it through a day or bringing up unlikely medical complications, all you're doing is increasing the fear. I can say, from personal experience and research, if you can make it 3-7 days, the biological stuff is an incredibly minor component. After that, it's all about working on decoupling the associations and finding new tools and strategies for regulating emotions.
Stopping is easier than you think. The really hard part is letting go of the idea that it's going to be this awful drawn out process and you'll never enjoy life again. You can literally yield huge benefits just days later.

I’ve grown up being told alcohol is bad for you and it’s not worth drinking. That was all largely tied to my religion as well. And as I’ve gotten older, I’ve decided that I will continue to not drink, and while I suspect part of that is simply me not wanting to be embarrassed or judged by the religious people in my life, it’s also because I understand that they actually have a point on this one. I do not think alcohol is some work of the devil or anything and I do not judge anyone who decides to use it. In fact, I respect people who drink responsibly. I just do not trust myself to be responsible with it, and I know just how dangerous it can be when it’s abused not just on my psychological and relational health, but on my physical health as well. I just don’t need another addiction in my life. I don’t need yet another maladaptive behavior causing me harm. I already have enough of those to worry about.

And I also think that alcohol just makes everything a bit riskier. Even going to the bar with friends is a bit riskier if everyone is drunk. The driver may not be 100% sober, you might make sexual decisions you don’t remember and would never approve of normally, people are more likely to take advantage of you while in such a vulnerable state (while being drunk), and people are more likely to inadvertently ignore the boundaries of others in any context while drunk. You could even end up in a fight that makes no sense and get injured. I mean none of that is particularly likely to happen, but it’s far more likely to happen when you’re drunk.

But hey, I get it. I’m just risk-averse, and that means I’m a total party-pooper. In the end, I just want people to be okay, and I want them to be happy and healthy. So I think people should enjoy alcohol, but be smart about it and do little things to reduce the risks. Like don’t go alone to a bar, and make sure at least one person is a true friend who will make sure you’re okay. Look out for each other or have someone there to look out for the group. Have a designated driver you can trust. Just little things. And obviously if you have an AUD, then don’t be afraid to get help for it. There’s no shame in that, in fact it’s very applaudable. Nobody needs to be ridiculous like me, I just think we need to respect alcohol and see it for what it is: a recreational drug. It’s harmless and can even enhance life if managed properly, but it can very easily destroy your life if it gets out of control. So respect it.

So... if you're looking for suggestions and happened across this comment, my suggestion would be a video on quitting sugar (at least the sweets).

I realize I very likely won a genetic lottery in that I have no real addictive traits. Been on oxy for serious pain from kidney stones, and while I was immensely grateful for the pain relief(if you've had them you how excruciating it is, if you haven't be VERY VERY thankful you haven't!), I did not enjoy the "high" from it at all, and genuinely can't understand being addicted to them. 2mins in and can already tell you this video is extremely over exaggerated for most all. You need to have very serious alcohol use to have delirium tremens. Like extreme. Not just people who have drank and drove lol (not that you should be doing that). Think moderate as someone who drinks a lot and for longer periods of time - like most every day starting at happy hour and drinking until 12am (so all time not at work). And think of severe as someone who drinks all day. That's when your nervous system starts to get affected in the ways they're describing here. For the normal drinker, even if you drink every day, if you're drinking for like 4hrs a night or even 5-6 liquor drinks a night, as long as you have that stopping point of not drinking during the day you can pretty much stop drinking and will just have a couple bad nights of sleep bc your brain is working on over drive since it's not being numbed like it's used to. To put it in simple terms.

98% of people don't need to be scared to stop drinking. You don't need a medical professional unless you're drinking all day every day for the most part. Otherwise, your body doesn't become 'dependent' like they're describing here.
